cards.html:
Rather excitingly for me, this is the first of these newsletters delivered using Ghost's improved newsletter support. The platform now has the ability to add content that only appears in the newsletter, not in the blog post it derives from. And so, if you're reading these words, I know you're reading the newsletter, not the blog post.

I've done this in the past - but manually. I published the email version first, and then went back and edited out the email-specific content afterwards. Now, I can do it all in the CMS before I press "publish". John and his team are doing really interesting things building a CMS built for a level of audience engagement work from the start. And it's exciting getting new features to explore every month or so.

You can read more about this new feature of Ghost over on their blog.

If you enjoyed this newsletter, please consider recommending it to others whom you think would find it useful. Like most writers, I'm highly dependent on recommendations for growth.

In the UK, the power of the media to change public opinion has been reasserted in dramatic form, as reports of the Prime Minister's closest aide's behaviour during lockdown broke out of the media bubble, and spread across the whole country. This is a significant move, because now it's stepped over this line, the company has to decide when it will do so in future, and in as consistent a manner as it can. Twitter has been one of the major vectors for the President to spread misinformation. Trying to cram the horse back into the stable and close the door is going to be a sisyphean task, if you'll excuse the mixed metaphor.

This should be shocking at a basic human level, let alone a corporate responsibility one. But we've all come to expect this from them, haven't we?

I'm not going to surprise anyone here by saying that this has been a rough couple of months for media businesses. The super short version is that there are three major streams of revenue for media companies right now:
The pandemic has brutalised two of those for the time being - and so, attention has shifted to the third: subscriptions. For some, the news has been good.

There's a lot more information on the subject in the INMA report by Grzegorz Piechota, which I was lucky enough to edit. It's a fascinating read, that explores in detail exactly which readers are becoming subscribers - and how you might go about retaning them.
